question: What is the primary challenge when using moving averages for prediction in time series data?
options: Computational complexity
The prediction lags behind actual trends
It cannot handle seasonal effects
It requires too many data points
answer: The prediction lags behind actual trends

question: In the component model of time series, which formula represents the multiplicative model?
options: Series = T + C + S + R
Series = T x C x S x R
Series = (T + C) x (S + R)
Series = T + (C x S x R)
answer: Series = T x C x S x R

question: Which method for handling missing values in time series data generally produces the most natural-looking results?
options: Replacing with the global average
Linear interpolation
Setting values to zero
Replacing with the previous value

question: What parameter is essential to configure when using Triple Exponential Smoothing (Holt-Winters Method) on data with seasonal patterns?
options: Learning rate
Cycle length (seasonal length)
Error threshold
Regression coefficient

question: Which of the following statements about autoregressive models is FALSE?
options: They can learn periodicities in the data
The weights for lag variables are learned from the data
They produce strictly linear predictions
They can be understood as regression trained on the time series itself

question: When analyzing the seasonal effect in a hotel occupancy rate time series, what does a seasonal index of 1.171 for Quarter 3 indicate?
options: Quarter 3 occupancy is 17.1% below the annual average
Quarter 3 occupancy is 17.1% above the annual average
Quarter 3 occupancy is 1.171 times the one of Quarter 2
Quarter 3 has the highest occupancy of all quarters
answer: Quarter 3 occupancy is 17.1% above the annual average

question: What is the main difference between Single and Double Exponential Smoothing?
options: Double Exponential Smoothing handles missing values
Double Exponential Smoothing accounts for the trend component
Double Exponential Smoothing uses two different smoothing factors
Double Exponential Smoothing applies the same smoothing twice
answer: Double Exponential Smoothing accounts for the trend component

question: Which evaluation approach is MOST appropriate for time series predictions?
options: Random k-fold cross-validation
Leave-one-out cross-validation
Sliding window evaluation or hold-out set at the end
Bootstrapping
answer: Sliding window evaluation or hold-out set at the end

question: What is the key difference between seasonal effects and cyclical effects in time series?
options: Seasonal effects are less predictable than cyclical effects
Seasonal effects occur at fixed intervals, cyclical do not
Seasonal effects can be modeled, but cyclical effects cannot
Seasonal effects are short-term, while cyclical effects are long-term
answer: Seasonal effects occur at fixed intervals, cyclical do not

question: When using lag variables for nominal prediction (such as weather forecasting), what needs to be created first?
options: A moving average baseline
A windowed representation of the data
A seasonal decomposition
A linear regression model
answer: A windowed representation of the data
